nodes.text: High public and external debt levels are systematically associated with poorer macroeconomic outcomes, in particular lower GDP growth and, in some cases, higher inflation
Empirical analysis uses a new multi-country historical dataset on central government (public) debt covering 44 countries and about 200 years with over 3,700 annual observations
For advanced economies (20 countries, 1946â€“2009), median GDP growth is roughly 1 percentage point lower and mean growth almost 4 percentage points lower when public debt/GDP exceeds 90 percent
For emerging market countries, public debt above 90 percent of GDP is associated with marked falls in median growth (to about 2.9 percent) and much larger declines in average growth
There is no systematic relationship between high public debt and inflation across advanced economies as a group
In emerging markets, higher public debt levels coincide with significantly higher inflation (median inflation more than doubles when debt rises above 90 percent)

External debt thresholds are lower for emerging markets: gross external debt above 60 percent of GDP is associated with about 2 percentage points lower annual growth, and above 90 percent growth rates are roughly cut in half or can be negative

Post-2007 financial crisis: public debt rose sharply (about 75 percent increase for crisis countries average; about 20 percent for non-crisis countries) and private debt often deleveraged, which can further dampen growth

Dataset includes central government debt (gross), external debt data from World Bank for public and private external debts, and long time series where available; some series start only around 2000 for external debt in advanced countries

Long-run (up to two centuries) country-level evidence yields similar conclusions: average growth when central government debt is above 90 percent is about 1.7 percent versus 3.7 percent when debt is below 30 percent
For emerging markets, external debt growth thresholds explain many historical defaults: over half of external debt defaults since 1970 occurred at debt levels above 60 percent
The nonlinear negative effect of debt on growth is consistent with 'debt intolerance' and likely operates via rising market interest rates that force fiscal adjustment or default
Excessive reliance on short-term borrowing and a shortening of debt maturity increase vulnerability to sudden confidence crises and abrupt adverse outcomes
Policy implication: traditional debt management (including attention to maturity structure and avoidance of excessive short-term external borrowing) should be prioritized to reduce vulnerability

Limitation: reliable data on private domestic debt are scarce across countries and time, so the paper focuses mainly on central government and external debts and cannot fully quantify private debt effects globally
